title: 14 top companies in the AGM shooting gallery
text:
A strike is a vote of 25 per cent or more against a company's remuneration report.

Last year's AGM season - right in the middle of the Hayne royal commission - was one of the most tumultuous since the two-strikes remuneration rule was introduced in 2011.

It left 18 top companies - including Westpac, ANZ and NAB, AMP, Telstra, Harvey Norman, Myer, QBE, Tabcorp, Goodman, Computershare and Healthscope - with investor strikes on pay, analysis by the Australian Shareholders Association (ASA) shows.

Atlassian co-founder Mike Cannon-Brookes has put pressure on BHP over climate activism. Bloomberg

Myer and Harvey Norman are among the leading companies scrambling to tweak their executive pay models in an effort to head off a shareholder revolt via a second strike which triggers a board spill.

Myer and Karoon Gas suffered second strikes last year but their directors defeated the resulting spill motions, resetting the clock and taking them out of the AGM shooting gallery this year.

That leaves 14 top companies still vulnerable to second strikes this year, after Westfield and Automotive Holdings were taken over and delisted.

Advertisement

The banks and AMP have been left stranded without clear guidelines on pay because the prudential regulator is setting new executive pay rules for financial firms which push for a weighting of 50 per cent for non-financial metrics. Investors have made plain they hate non-financial metrics for pay.

Dearth of diversity

The Australian Council of Superannuation Investors said it would recommend the industry super sector target David Teoh's TPG Telecom this year because there isn't any women on the company's board.

There remain seven top 200 companies with no women on their boards and ACSI said that would be a key focus this year.

“Investors have been crystal clear when it comes to greater gender diversity on boards – zero women boards are not fit for purpose," the council's CEO Louise Davidson said.

"ACSI will be recommending a vote against boards that have made no progress on this front following extensive engagement on the issue.”

Ms Davidson said the fallout of the Hayne commission and the potential to focus on individual directors was also front of mind.

'Bonus persistence'

Advertisement

"We are all aware of the issue of bonus persistence in the ASX200. Investors will be looking closely this AGM season to ensure pay matches performance.”

Shareholder association head of policy Fiona Balzer said it would focus on the makeup of boards this year, after individual directors were singled out last year.

"We’re focussing on board composition after the Royal Commission, APRA and ASIC findings showed the boards were failing to cut through a lot of data and get to maximum effectiveness," she said.

The ASA said it "we're challenging ourselves this year to identify target remuneration as well as maximum opportunity", warning that while some remuneration reports like BHP and CSL are clear others remain opaque.

The ASA will vote against Brambles' remuneration this week, arguing the executives' fixed pay is generous and the potential variable pay excessive.

"We’re on the lookout for non-financial indicators we can support as triggers for financial reward – post royal commission and regulator guidelines – other than safety and environment metrics, these measures look like a 'gimme' and I don’t think anyone wants that."

Climate concerns

Head of proxy firm ISS in Australia Vasili Kolesnikoff pointed to the rise of climate and social resolutions by activists "signalling some disruption to AGMs and friction with boards on climate and social issues".

BHP is facing a fresh push from shareholders including superannuation funds and Atlassian founder Mike Cannon-Brookes to suspend its ties with associations including the Minerals Council of Australia, claiming they are failing to do enough on climate change.

And Origin has hit back at five climate-related resolutions proposed for its October 1 AGM, telling investors in a 21-page response: "Origin believes the resolutions requisitioned by a minority of shareholders do not have comprehensive regard to Origin's current targets, policies and practices and many of the assertions lack scientific rigour or peer review or are incorrect."
description: Board spills are on the cards as directors get ready to face shareholders fired up over issues ranging from pay and bonuses to diversity and climate change.
